messages: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:00): like I don't know the deep reason <nobr> and <wbr> are nonconforming
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:00): maybe just because they never were conforming before?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:00): I would guess it's because, unlike <pre> and <br>, they were not in any previous spec.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:01): They don't feel entirely semantic to me. Line breaking (or not) is fairly deep into CSS territory.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:01): Then why doesn't that apply to <pre>?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:01): Of course, <wbr> can't really be emulated
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:01): Also, as Maciej points out, <wbr> can't be emulated -- yeah.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:02): I'm also planning to file a bug requesting that most or all presentational attributes/elements be made conforming (possibly obsolete but conforming so they throw an error).  Something like <table cellpadding=5> is difficult to reproduce exactly in inline CSS, and even more difficult to convert automatically.  And some, like cellspacing, have no direct CSS equivalent that works in (for example) IE6.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:02): <pre> is different, because it says the whitespace is significant
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:02): s/so they throw an error/so they raise a warning/
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:02): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, <nobr> says line breaks are significant.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:03): What does it do?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:03): has never used it
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:03): It prevents line breaking
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:03): <pre> gives meaning to the whitespace within it. <nobr> is just a formatting guideline.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:03): Then what does Maciej mean by "<nobr> should be considered just as semantic as <pre> or <br>, with a semantic of 'a block of text with preformatted line breaks.'"?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:03): It's not preformatted line breaks, it just doesn't have any line breaks.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:04): That does seem like CSS territory to me.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:04): <wbr> less so, because it's hard to see how you'd even implement such a feature in CSS -- it inherently requires a particular point to be flagged in the markup itself.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:05): It's surely angels and pins territory, but to me <pre> is a clear step away from <br>, <wbr>, <nobr>
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:06): Really?  <br> and <wbr> seem like they have to be in HTML to me.  <nobr> I agree with you on, more or less.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:06): They have to be, but only because we can't express it any other way
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:06): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Sam Ruby has a bug open specifically about some particular examples of presentational table markup
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:07): <nobr> really means "there are no line breaks here".
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:07): <wbr> is sort of like &shy;
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:07): let me see if I can find it
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:07): http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7468
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:07): (only there's no hyphen involved, obviously)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:08): I guess I described <nobr> incorrectly in my bug
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:08): "This use case is handled by <style scoped> in HTML5."
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:08): That's actually a good point.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:08): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: that's the one
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:08): Once that's supported, the table markup could be easily replaced.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (04:08): Well, zzz time, *poof*
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:09): I'm not sure I buy that argument
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:09): about <style scoped>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:09): I guess it is more compact than putting a style= attribute on every cell, but it's probably still less compact than the presentational attributes
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:09): and it's not clear to me that the accessibility / media independence argument applies in this particular case
61831986744b882b4371990cc1863b19 (04:11): ooh, if we added <nobr> and <wbr> to html5, ppk's compatibility tables could finally validate

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:11): I think the real argument in favor of pushing for the use of CSS is consistency.  There's never any actual difference between using presentational markup and equivalent inline CSS, but CSS is a much more powerful and general mechanism, and is the only styling mechanism to be supported going forward.  A language that didn't include presentational markup beyond inline style would be much simpler.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:11): I don't know whether that's a good enough reason to make them invalid, though, rather than obsolete but conforming.
40cddb5ac261f4694179715cd8424278 (04:12): http://www.quirksmode.org/oddsandends/wbr.html
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:12): I think whitespace treatment is something that is on the fine edge between semantics and presentation
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:13): sometimes, a particular whitespace treatment is really part of the information in the document, not just a matter of how you present it
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:19): Poetry and computer code are standard examples of that.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (04:19): Although <pre> usually suffices for both, if you suppress the monotype font for poetry.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:16): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c et al.: I just filed a bug "Many, most, or all obsolete features should be conforming".  http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9355
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:18): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: I would recommend filing bugs that are narrower in scope than that
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:18): Really?  Why?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:18): I give clear reasoning that applies to *all* obsolete features.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:18): I.e., I argue that features should not be non-conforming merely because they're obsolete.  The same logic applies to nearly all features that are non-conforming because they're obsolete.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:18): I don't see how I would be able to narrow the bug.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:19): None of the features that are non-conforming "merely because they're obsolete"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:19): It looks like they are to me.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:19): obsolete is a specific subcategory of "non-conforming"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:19): it is not a justification, it is a label
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:19): the rationale for things being noncomforming is in the new section Hixie just added
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:20): Maybe I missed it.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:20): The various features are listed as being obsolete, and the only hint as to why is that alternative markup is suggested.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:20): I mean, as non-conforming.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:20): hang on, waiting for spec to load
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:21): it used to be there was no in-sepc rationale that said why those things are nonconforming

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:21): The implication (to me) is that the only reason they're non-conforming is because these other features exist, which are in most cases exactly equivalent but are considered better for various reasons.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:21): They can't actually be very much better if they're functionally identical, of course.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:38): Okay, well, I'm going to bed.  If you have specific suggestions for how I should split up the bug or any further points that I should address, 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, feel free to ping me to tell me of them.

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:39): that states many individual reasons for particular author conformance requirements
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:39): none of the justifications amounts to "is obsolete"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:39): you may disagree with some of them, or you may feel some things marked obsolete and nonconforming when none of those criteria apply
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:40): I didn't know about that.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:40): yeah, it's new
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:40): I'll look it over and amend the bug report accordingly, when I have time.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:40): Hixie added that in response to bug 7034
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:40): I think your bug is arguably just a duplicate of bug 7034
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:40): (which is titled "remove or replace author conformance requirements")
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:41): I guess it is slightly less narrow in that it's limited to the obsolete section
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:41): No, I only argue for removing a subset of them.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:41): but that's kind of arbitrary
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:41): There are lots of author conformance requirements that I think are a good idea.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:41): For instance, they can help to catch authoring mistakes.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:41): note that not everything in the obsolete section is even presentational, though much of your argument is about presentational markups pecifically

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:41): Or inform authors of areas where they might be running into interoperability problems, or pressure authors to do something that we have good reason to want them to do (e.g., alt="").
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:42): Thus the many/most/all in the bug summary.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:42): Much of it applies to all of them, I think.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:43): It looks like the justification for presentational markup offers no arguments that couldn't equally apply to style="".
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:43): that's why it gives a specific reason for exempting style=""
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:43): which you may or may not agree with
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:43): I think a bug about just presentational markup might make sense
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:43): Maybe I'll repurpose it.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:43): I don't see how your argument applies to, say, <bgsound>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:43): or <applet>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:44): or <frameset>
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:44): I don't know what the first two do, really.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:44): but if you make the bug be about that, then I suggest you should address Ian's argument in the rationale
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:44): well if you don't know what they do, you probably don't have enough info to suggest they should be conforming :-)

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:44): <frameset> is something that's banned because it's considered to be something authors should almost never do, because it has serious problems, although they might be tempted to do it.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:44): Which is why I didn't say all obsolete features should be conforming.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:45): if you say many/most/all, then you are asking someone else to guess what you mean
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:46): all I'm saying is, make it clear enough that no one has to guess which ones you have in mind
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (05:46): I guess I can present a narrow argument, and he can extend it to everything else it applies to if he likes.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:47): well, even "presentational" is a fairly clear category, though there may be edge cases that are hard to judge

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:48): most obsolete nonconforming features are that way for reason of being presentational it seems, but there are quite a few exceptions which generally have an independent and plausible reason to be banned
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (05:49): anyway, this is mainly my advice on how to make a good bug report - if you choose to do nothing, then the project won't blow up or anything, but
